project.teaser: The general objective of sHYpS is to support the decarbonisation of the shipping industry, by leveraging on previous and on-going work and investment made by Viking and some consortium members. It will develop a hydrogen-based solution, which can be adapted to...
project.objective: The general objective of sHYpS is to support the decarbonisation of the shipping industry, by leveraging on previous and on-going work and investment made by Viking and some consortium members. It will develop a hydrogen-based solution, which can be adapted to multiple types of vessels and in some cases can already achieve IMO’s target for 2030 and 2050. The project will develop a (i) novel hydrogen storage intermodal 45’ ISO c-type container, (ii) the complete detailed design of modular containerised powertrain based on optimised PEM Fuel Cells and (iii) their dedicated logistics. On one hand the project will define a logistic based on swapping pre-filled containers, on the other hand it will define a perspective scale-up of the storage capacity and the supply applied to the Port of Bergen use-case. This will allow to kick start a supply-chain without waiting for the full infrastructure to be in place. We show how this approach can already support a remarkable part of the vessels in the EU waters. The project will use the window of opportunity of 1 Viking’s newbuilds Ocean Cruise vessel to install the storage system onboard with the complete gas handling and energy management system and test it during the shakedown cruise by 2026, with a limited power Fuel Cell. When the 6MW will be in place (pendent investment decision by Viking) this will allow to cut 50% of emissions in a 14 days fjord cruise. The midterm outcomes are remarkable, since Viking has a building program of 6 Ocean Cruise ships by 2030 and several river ships. With the right logistics in place the ISO container technology can develop in hundreds of units per year. In the meantime, the upscaled design of the container from this project will approach more segments in sea and IWW application and look to hundreds of vessels in the order book of commercial fleets. The value-chain include LH2 suppliers, giving the opportunity to speed up a supply of thousands tons of LH2 per year in the next 20 years.
project.title: sustainable HYdrogen powered Shipping
project.keywords: hydrogen propulsion, hydrogen supply, shipping, IMO 2030, decarbonisation, ship propulsion, GHG reduction

article.title: Novel hydrogen technology could accelerate the transition to zero-emission shipping

result.title: The role of hydrogen as enabler of industrial port area decarbonization

details.authors: Pivetta, D.; Dall’Armi, C.; Sandrin, P.; Bogar, M.; Taccani, R.

result.title: D9.4 - Data Management Plan
result.description: The DMP, as part of making research data findable, accessible, interoperable and re-usable (FAIR), will include information on the handling of research data during and after the end of the project; what data will be collected, processed and/or generated; which methodology & standards will be applied; whether data will be shared/made open access and how data will be curated and preserved (including after the end of the project). Document will be revised towards the end of the project.

result.title: A small angle X-ray scattering approach for investigating fuel cell catalyst degradation for both ex situ and in operando analyses

details.authors: Bogar M., Yakovlev Y., Novakova J., Darabut A.M., Kriechbaum M., Amenitsch H., Taccani R., Matolínova I.

result.title: D8.4 - Preliminary report on dissemination and communication activities
result.description: The report will contain the periodic reporting on the communication and dissemination activities. Description of the conferences, international events and other events, where the consortium took part, or publications made by the consortium members.

result.title: D9.2 - Project Management plan
result.description: Planning and description of the coordination activities with reference to the project monitoring. In particular with reference to the interrelation between the work packages of the project and technical advances in each work package through a close interaction with all work package leaders. The report will contain also the activities that will be performed for the observation of external developments in order to introduce the necessary actions for strategic adaptation of the project.

details.authors: Pivetta D. , Volpato G., Carraro G., Dall'Armi C., Da Lio L., Lazzaretto A., Taccani R.

result.title: D8.2 - Dissemination and Communication Plan
result.description: The report will contain a description of the dissemination and communication plan set up for the project. The plan will include the following elements:•A roadmap of main interesting channels, conferences, or any international event (fairs, expositions, etc.) where the project could be promoted and disseminated.•The “branding” of the project (including visual Logo, pay-off(s), dissemination lay-outs, templates of leaflets, newsletters, website, documents, etc.•A comprehensive schedule of the dissemination activities of the project, with details on the timing, the roles of involved partners (or external contributors), stakeholders’ groups to be targeted and tools to be used, etc.

result.title: D8.7 - Second report on dissemination and communication activities
result.description: The report will contain the periodic reporting on the communication and dissemination activities. Description of the conferences, international events and other events, where the consortium took part, or publications made by the consortium members in the period from M18 to M30.

result.title: Multi-objective operational optimization of a multi-energy liquid air energy storage (LAES) in a hydrogen-based green energy hub in Singapore

details.authors: Tafone A., Pivetta D., Taccani R., Del Mondo F., Mazzoni S., Romagnoli A.

result.title: D9.3 - Quality management plan
result.description: The quality management plan will describe the actions that will be taken for the project continuous checking for results and that the achievements are in line with the objectives and standards fixed. and to ensure that the project orientations, activities and outcomes are efficiently answering the needs of the European community. Also, the objective is to ensure a timely completion of all deliverables in accordance with the work plan and provide quality information. The general processes for quality management, includes the definition of a quality assurance plan.

category.title: fuel cells
category.displayCode: /engineering and technology/environmental engineering/energy and fuels/fuel cells

category.title: Digital agenda
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development of digital technologies and the digitisation of the economy and society (known as ‘Digital transition’).

category.title: Clean air
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the clean air policy (National Emission Ceiling Directive) aiming to improve ambient air quality and tackle air pollution, to protect the environment and human health.

category.title: Artificial intelligence
category.description: This tracker monitors Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to the development and deployment of AI-based technologies and solutions. Projects that develop AI-tools as part of their research method are included

category.title: Climate action
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to both mitigating climate change (e.g., contributions to the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions) and adapting to climate change by building resilience (e.g., regarding floods, droughts, spatial planning and better governance, adaptation to changing climate in value chains, etc.).

category.title: Biodiversity
category.description: This tracker monitors the Horizon Europe’s financial contribution to Europe’s biodiversity’s path to recovery including species protection, ecosystem conservation, and habitat rehabilitation, all essential for resilience in climate adaptation and addressing ecosystem services but also environmental crime and the health-environment connection.
